Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Polymer-Supported Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP) Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Frieder Jaekle of Rutgers University at Newark will apply recent advances in the activation of small molecules by frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) to polymer-supported catalysis. A multi-pronged approach will be taken: (1) soluble polymers will be pursued that are functionalized with strong Lewis acid (acceptor) and/or Lewis base (donor) sites (amines, phosphines, carbenes), which are sterically encumbered to allow for formation of "frustrated" Lewis pairs. (2) Innovative approaches to porous polymers that contain catalytically active Lewis acid and Lewis base groups will also be developed. The efficacy of these new materials in catalytic processes will be examined. In addition to the societal benefits of developing sustainable chemistry processes, the broader impacts of the project include the training of undergraduate and graduate students in a highly interdisciplinary research environment, involvement of students from groups underrepresented in chemistry (e.g. ACS Project SEED high school students, minority undergraduate students), and creating awareness of sustainability in chemistry through a Polymer and Materials Chemistry Outreach Program. The Professor Jaekle will also organize the "Boron in the Americas" meeting in 2014 at the Rutgers-Newark campus.

The proposed work addresses the need for new sustainable chemistry processes by developing metal-free catalysts for accelerating chemical reactions. Successful preparation of the proposed catalysts is expected to have an impact in many areas that employ catalysis, such as fine chemical synthesis, refining, and plastics manufacturing. Additionally, this research could lead to new processes available that will reduce reliance on rare and costly metals, toxic byproducts, as well as the amounts of chemical waste generated.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Newark
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of this project new methods have been developed for the synthesis of boron-containing polymeric Lewis acids and bases. With a view toward applications as supported, reusable catalysts and in small molecule activation, materials were designed that display good stability as well as high activity. Due to their electron-deficient character organoborane functionalities are uniquely suited. Specifically, we have (a) synthesized organosilyl-functionalized styrene and norbornene-based monomers and polymers as precursors to highly Lewis acidic triarylborane polymers; (b) developed new approaches to Lewis acidic borinic acid-functionalized monomers and polymers; (c) prepared monomers and polymers that are functionalized with Lewis basic borate and H-bonding azaborinine moieties; and (d) pursued porous cross-linked materials with strongly Lewis basic amine sites that can be easily recycled.

The grant enabled the training of 1 postdoctoral researcher, 2 graduate students, and 5 undergraduate students. In addition, 3 high school students were provided with an opportunity to participate in the research program over the summer months. These students were trained in scientific methods such as multinuclear NMR, GC-MS, MALDI-MS, handling of air-sensitive compounds by Schlenk and glove box techniques, monomer synthesis and purification, and in polymerization techniques. They were also mentored in respect to scientific writing and presentation skills.

Serving the broader science community, the PI completed a review on “Recent Advances in the Synthesis and Applications of Organoborane Polymers”, which is expected to serve as general reference for researchers in the field. Moreover, with colleagues from Japan and Korea, the PI co-organized a 2-day research symposium on “Functional Materials Based on Organic-inorganic Hybrid Polymers” at the 2015 Pacifichem Meeting. In addition, the PI delivered a tutorial lecture on “Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers” in the Chemical Education Division of the American Chemical Society (ACS) with the aim of stimulating efforts to teach polymer content in undergraduate inorganic courses.

In terms of local outreach efforts, the PI organized several high school visits to Rutgers University. In total about 100 students, many of them from minority-serving schools, had an opportunity to experience current research efforts in materials chemistry first hand, while also learning about college applications, curricula, and opportunities for support.


Last Modified: 11/24/2016
Modified by: Frieder Jaekle

The grant enabled the training of 1 postdoctoral researcher, 2 graduate students, and 5 undergraduate students.
